musicalLanguage.description: Robert Johnson recorded this in 1936 and it became the anthem of Chicago blues. The shuffle groove is infectious — once you start, your foot will not stop tapping. The boogie-woogie left hand drives the train while the right hand plays a simple, singable melody.
musicalLanguage.structure: 12-bar blues with shuffle feel. This excerpt: first 8 bars
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: E7 shuffle — the left hand boogie pattern locks in the groove immediately
Bar 3-4: E7 continues — repetition builds the hypnotic feel
Bar 5-6: A7 — IV chord shift. The boogie pattern moves with it.
Bar 7-8: E7 — back home. The shuffle never stops.
teachingGoals: Basic 12-bar blues in E — a guitar-friendly key for jamming
Keeping a steady groove while adding simple right-hand melody
styleTips: The left hand is the engine — keep it absolutely steady
Shuffle means triplet feel on the eighths: long-SHORT long-SHORT
Right hand melody is secondary — the groove is what matters most

measures.teachingNote: E7 — ascending through the chord. Left hand establishes the boogie bass: E-B-E-B.
E7 — melody comes back down. Keep the left hand pumping.
E7 — the G natural sliding to G# is the blue note. That is the soul of this song.
E7 — simplify with half notes. Rest your right hand while the left keeps going.
A7 — IV chord! Same boogie pattern shifted to A. The melody transposes too.
A7 — descending. The G natural is gone here — A7 uses G# (its major 7th would be G#).
E7 — back home. Same as bar 1. The groove is a circle.
E7 — descending to D4 (the b7). Setting up for the turnaround V chord.
